{"data": {"blog": {"enhancing-communities-on-devhub-2038": {"": "At DevHub, we believe that strong communities are essential to a thriving NEAR developer ecosystem. That\\\\u{2019}s why we\\\\u{2019}re excited to announce new features that will make it easier for communities to collaborate, share knowledge, and contribute to innovation.\\\\n\\\\n \\\\n\\\\n\\\\n##### Discover Communities\\\\n\\\\nWhether you\\\\u{2019}re a seasoned NEAR contributor or a new developer exploring our ecosystem, finding relevant information and groups can be challenging. That\\\\u{2019}s why we\\\\u{2019}ve created a [dedicated community directory](https://near.org/devgovgigs.near/widget/app?page=communities) within DevHub. Here, you can quickly explore a wide range of communities, each focused on specific topics such as Zero Knowledge or Contract Standards. Stay up to date with the latest activities and connect with like-minded individuals who share your interest.\\\\n\\\\n![](https://ipfs.near.social/ipfs/bafkreifemienjpongd4cejldovbr22w7nokbw7r3oameecdcvs6bppkuji)\\\\n\\\\n##### Create & Manage Communities\\\\n\\\\nAre you passionate about a specific topic? You can now create and manage your very own community on DevHub. Add content, curate discussions, and customize the appearance. With these tools, you can shape the narrative and cultivate an engaging space where members can share expertise, ask questions, and learn from one another.\\\\n\\\\n![](https://ipfs.near.social/ipfs/bafkreigkcfyjobpz5ajx2gjtr2gvhafzz4wqmm5z7p3rio5hkusgonpsee)\\\\n\\\\n##### Enhanced Community Profiles\\\\n\\\\nWe\\\\u{2019}ve completely redesigned the homepage for each community on DevHub. Now, each community features a unique header and profile image that visually reflects its purpose. We\\\\\\'ve also added an activity feed that displays the latest discussions within your community.\\\\n\\\\n![](https://ipfs.near.social/ipfs/bafkreiei7abgdv243akttbxdwqvk3g5e34iyflj3kkswodjao6thqkspfe)\\\\n\\\\n##### Integrations with 3rd Party Tools\\\\n\\\\nLastly, we\\\\u{2019}ve added Telegram and GitHub integrations to make it easier to find everything in one place. Now your community can easily display the latest messages from its Telegram channel or activity from GitHub repositories.\\\\n\\\\n![](https://ipfs.near.social/ipfs/bafkreic2gvxygfkkaunee3bvt3ciqr3qfsube4tbkqpt6imk2o2ymjuv6u)\\\\n\\\\nWe hope that these changes will make it easier for you to foster stronger connections and shape our ecosystem. Stay tuned for more changes coming soon!\\\\n\\\\n", "metadata": {"id": "2038", "title": "Enhancing Communities on DevHub", "author": "bearmans.near", "status": "DRAFT", "category": "news", "subtitle": "Discover and connect with other developers in the NEAR community", "createdAt": "2023-11-03", "updatedAt": "2023-11-03", "description": "Discover and connect with other developers in the NEAR community", "publishedAt": "2023-11-03", "communityAddonId": "blogv2"}}}}, "handle": "developer-dao"}

{"data": {"blog": {"introducing-community-announcements-2943": {"": "Ever miss out on important NEAR events or updates because they got buried on NEAR Social, Telegram, or some random Discord thread? We hear you loud and clear. Juggling scattered updates across multiple channels is not fun. That\\\\u{2019}s why we\\\\u{2019}re thrilled to introduce Community Announcements, your streamlined channel for staying in the loop with your favorite topics.\\\\n\\\\n![](https://ipfs.near.social/ipfs/bafkreichvq32kr45lmovgc2j2ndqmti5l3nd44g3gyqzxydtoix5wmzfje)\\\\n\\\\nModerators now have a dedicated space right on the homepage of each community to share the latest news, events, and insights. Did you miss an important update or discussion? No worries, just head to the announcement feed to catch up at your own pace.\\\\n\\\\nAnd the best part? Announcements are tightly integrated with NEAR Social, so you can subscribe to these announcements directly within your feed. But the conversation doesn\\\\u{2019}t stop there. Our upcoming Discussion feature will give each community a dedicated space for people to engage, ask questions, and share their perspectives.\\\\n\\\\nExplore the feeds in your communities today! And keep an eye out for even more exciting features coming soon.", "metadata": {"id": "2943", "title": "Introducing Community Announcements", "author": "theori.near", "status": "DRAFT", "category": "guide", "subtitle": "Stay in the loop with your favorite communities on DevHub", "createdAt": "2024-02-09", "updatedAt": "2024-02-09", "description": "Stay in the loop with your favorite communities on DevHub", "publishedAt": "2024-02-09", "communityAddonId": "blogv2"}}}}, "handle": "developer-dao"}

{"data": {"blog": {"devhub-streamlines-funding-3251": {"": "We\\\\\\'re excited to announce a major upgrade to DevHub that transforms the funding journey! After collaborating with hundreds of community contributors and organizations, we\\\\u{2019}ve completely revamped the proposal submission and funding process. This makes it easier to submit, review, and approve proposals aligned with DevDAO\\\\u{2019}s mission of fostering a thriving NEAR developer community.\\\\n\\\\nExplore the new experience on the [Proposal Feed](https://near.social/devhub.near/widget/app?page=proposals).\\\\n\\\\n## What\\\\u{2019}s new?\\\\n* **A Clear Journey:** Our new structured proposal format and dedicated feed make it easy to understand requirements and submit proposals to DevDAO.\\\\n* **Enhanced Transparency:** Track progress and understand the rationale behind funding decisions with clear updates and timelines.\\\\n* **KYC/KYB Integration:** Verification with Fractal helps establish the identity of recipients, prompting trust and compliance.\\\\n* **Focused Collaboration:** Better tools for all participants to actively discuss, comment, and collaborate within each proposal.\\\\n* **Decentralized & Transparent Decisions:** Community involvement and clear rationale guide funding choices, fostering trust in the process.\\\\n\\\\n## Pilot Program with DevDAO\\\\nFor the initial launch, the new proposal experience offers a clear and organized way to submit and manage funding requests specifically from DevDAO, the main entity behind DevHub. We focus on funding projects that drive developer growth:\\\\n\\\\n* **DevTools**: SDKs, CLIs, IDEs, and documentation (Rust and JS stacks) that streamline development.\\\\n* **DevRel**: Activities that onboard and engage developers including tutorials, guides, onboarding experiences, community support channels, and IRL/online events.\\\\n* **DevHub Portal**: Building essential tools for managing proposals, treasury, and community collaboration.\\\\n\\\\n## Get Involved\\\\nThe DevHub Portal is a vibrant hub where diverse communities connect, collaborate, and find resources for building on NEAR. The new proposal experience streamlines a key aspect \\\\u{2013} funding for developer-centric projects.\\\\n\\\\n* **Have a proposal?** Head over to the [Proposal Feed](https://near.social/devhub.near/widget/app?page=proposals).\\\\n* **Need guidance?** Review our detailed [funding guidelines](https://near.social/devhub.near/widget/app?page=community&handle=developer-dao&tab=funding).\\\\n* **Want to connect?** Catch the latest announcements and join the discussions in our various [communities](https://near.social/devhub.near/widget/app?page=communities).\\\\n\\\\n## What About the Old Activity Feed?\\\\nDon\\\\\\'t worry, the conversations from the old activity feed are still archived [here](https://near.social/devhub.near/widget/app?page=feed)!\\\\n\\\\n## What\\\\u{2019}s next?\\\\nThis pilot phase with DevDAO focuses on streamlining the funding process, laying the groundwork for a model that can empower other organizations within the NEAR ecosystem. We\\\\u{2019}re working on further automating the process and creating tools for efficient decision-making and treasury management. Your feedback is crucial. Let us know how we can improve by contributing to the discussions in the [DevHub Portal](https://near.social/devhub.near/widget/app?page=community&handle=devhub-platform&tab=discussions) community.\\\\n", "metadata": {"id": "3251", "title": "DevHub Streamlines Funding", "author": "theori.near", "status": "DRAFT", "category": "news", "subtitle": "Introducing the New Proposal Experience for DevDAO", "createdAt": "2024-03-22", "updatedAt": "2024-03-22", "description": "Introducing the New Proposal Experience for DevDAO", "publishedAt": "2024-03-22", "communityAddonId": "blogv2"}}}}, "handle": "developer-dao"}

{"data": {"blog": {"near-bounty-booster-3286": {"": "### Hey developers \\\\u{1f44b}!\\\\n  \\\\nWelcome to **NEAR\\\\\\'s Bounty Booster Program**. If you participate in any hackathon and choose to build on NEAR, you\\\\\\'ll have the chance to earn additional rewards!! We\\\\\\'ll boost your winning prize with additional rewards, giving you the support you need to keep building. So, don\\\\\\'t miss out on this incredible opportunity to showcase your skills. \\\\n\\\\n  \\\\n#### 1. How It Works \\\\u{1f929} : \\\\nParticipate in any hackathon NEAR is not sponsoring, submit a project utilizing the NEAR stack, and if you win...get ready for a bounty boost! We\\\\\\'ll match a percentage of your prize money, up to $5,000 per team. \\\\n\\\\n`EXAMPLE`: if your team wins a $2,000 prize at a hackathon and the NEAR DevHub team determines a match percentage of 50% for your submission, NEAR will boost your winnings with an additional $1000!!!\\\\n\\\\nIt\\\\\\'s that simple! Any developer anywhere in the world can benefit from the support and resources provided by **NEAR DevHub** if they choose to build on the NEAR ecosystem.\\\\n\\\\n  \\\\n#### 2. Application Process \\\\u{270d}\\\\u{fe0f} :\\\\n\\\\n- Submit your project to a **non-NEAR-sponsored hackathon**.\\\\n\\\\n- Your project must utilize tools provided by NEAR, including **Chain Abstraction, React-on-Chain, Smart Contracts in Rust (Rust, JS, AssemblyScript), SDK, and other related tools**.\\\\n\\\\n- Tweet about your submission, mentioning the hackathon, @NEARDevHub, and using hashtags: `#NEARBountyBooster, #extralife, #NEARDevHub, and #NEAR.`\\\\n\\\\n- Complete the NEAR Bounty Booster application \\\\u{1f449} [form](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfmVN4n_A0mduNVjF4PAlhllr7nQo4Xjlsei1fcA5Wvruqo2A/viewform?usp=sf_link) with project details.\\\\n\\\\n- You can submit multiple applications, but each project must be distinct.\\\\n\\\\n- Use this [sample tweet](https://typefully.com/t/bHCRD5z) as a guide.\\\\n\\\\n  \\\\n#### 3. Verification and Payment \\\\u{2705} :\\\\n- The NEAR Bounty Booster committee will verify the eligibility of the hacker team and their winning project based on the information provided in the application form and the tweet.\\\\n\\\\n- Once verified, the matched bounty amount will be paid to the hacker team within 30 days of the application submission.\\\\n  \\\\n\\\\n***Please pay attention to the terms and conditions below***\\\\n  \\\\n#### Terms & Conditions \\\\u{1f468}\\\\u{1f3fc}\\\\u{200d}\\\\u{2696}\\\\u{fe0f} : \\\\n- The exact percentage matched is determined by the NEAR DevHub team on a case-by-case basis, ensuring the program can adapt to the unique circumstances of each project and developer.\\\\n\\\\n- Each project must be distinct from the ones previously submitted for the Bounty Booster program.\\\\n\\\\n- To be considered to have \\\\\\\"won\\\\\\\" a prize, the hacker team must have been awarded one of the general prizes or sponsor-specific bounties offered by the hackathon organizers..\\\\n\\\\n- The NEAR Bounty Booster committee reserves the right to reject any application if there is an attempt to abuse the program.\\\\n\\\\n- By participating in the NEAR Bounty Booster program, hacker teams agree to these terms and conditions. The NEAR Bounty Booster committee reserves the right to modify these terms and conditions without prior notice.\\\\n\\\\n  \\\\n##### Happy Building!\\\\n", "metadata": {"id": "undefined", "title": "NEAR Bounty Booster ", "author": "victorkanu1.near", "status": "DRAFT", "category": "guide", "subtitle": "", "createdAt": "2024-04-24", "updatedAt": "2024-04-24", "description": "", "publishedAt": "2024-04-24", "communityAddonId": "blogv2"}}}}, "handle": "developer-dao"}

{"data": {"blog": {"devhub-streamlines-funding-3251": {"": "We\\\\\\'re excited to announce a major upgrade to DevHub that transforms the funding journey! After collaborating with hundreds of community contributors and organizations, we\\\\u{2019}ve completely revamped the proposal submission and funding process. This makes it easier to submit, review, and approve proposals aligned with DevDAO\\\\u{2019}s mission of fostering a thriving NEAR developer community.\\\\n\\\\nExplore the new experience on the [Proposal Feed](https://near.social/devhub.near/widget/app?page=proposals).\\\\n\\\\n## What\\\\u{2019}s new?\\\\n* **A Clear Journey:** Our new structured proposal format and dedicated feed make it easy to understand requirements and submit proposals to DevDAO.\\\\n* **Enhanced Transparency:** Track progress and understand the rationale behind funding decisions with clear updates and timelines.\\\\n* **KYC/KYB Integration:** Verification with Fractal helps establish the identity of recipients, prompting trust and compliance.\\\\n* **Focused Collaboration:** Better tools for all participants to actively discuss, comment, and collaborate within each proposal.\\\\n* **Decentralized & Transparent Decisions:** Community involvement and clear rationale guide funding choices, fostering trust in the process.\\\\n\\\\n## Pilot Program with DevDAO\\\\nFor the initial launch, the new proposal experience offers a clear and organized way to submit and manage funding requests specifically from DevDAO, the main entity behind DevHub. We focus on funding projects that drive developer growth:\\\\n\\\\n* **DevTools**: SDKs, CLIs, IDEs, and documentation (Rust and JS stacks) that streamline development.\\\\n* **DevRel**: Activities that onboard and engage developers including tutorials, guides, onboarding experiences, community support channels, and IRL/online events.\\\\n* **DevHub Portal**: Building essential tools for managing proposals, treasury, and community collaboration.\\\\n\\\\n## Get Involved\\\\nThe DevHub Portal is a vibrant hub where diverse communities connect, collaborate, and find resources for building on NEAR. The new proposal experience streamlines a key aspect \\\\u{2013} funding for developer-centric projects.\\\\n\\\\n* **Have a proposal?** Head over to the [Proposal Feed](https://near.social/devhub.near/widget/app?page=proposals).\\\\n* **Need guidance?** Review our detailed [funding guidelines](https://near.social/devhub.near/widget/app?page=community&handle=developer-dao&tab=funding).\\\\n* **Want to connect?** Catch the latest announcements and join the discussions in our various [communities](https://near.social/devhub.near/widget/app?page=communities).\\\\n\\\\n## What About the Old Activity Feed?\\\\nDon\\\\\\'t worry, the conversations from the old activity feed are still archived [here](https://near.social/devhub.near/widget/app?page=feed)!\\\\n\\\\n## What\\\\u{2019}s next?\\\\nThis pilot phase with DevDAO focuses on streamlining the funding process, laying the groundwork for a model that can empower other organizations within the NEAR ecosystem. We\\\\u{2019}re working on further automating the process and creating tools for efficient decision-making and treasury management. Your feedback is crucial. Let us know how we can improve by contributing to the discussions in the [DevHub Portal](https://near.social/devhub.near/widget/app?page=community&handle=devhub-platform&tab=discussions) community.\\\\n", "metadata": {"id": "3251", "title": "DevHub Streamlines Funding", "author": "theori.near", "status": "DRAFT", "category": "news", "subtitle": "Introducing the New Proposal Experience for DevDAO", "createdAt": "2024-03-22", "updatedAt": "2024-03-22", "description": "Introducing the New Proposal Experience for DevDAO", "publishedAt": "2024-03-22", "communityAddonId": "blogv2"}}}}, "handle": "developer-dao"}

{"data": {"blog": {"near-bounty-booster-3286": {"": "### Hey developers \\\\u{1f44b}!\\\\n  \\\\nWelcome to **NEAR\\\\\\'s Bounty Booster Program**. If you participate in any hackathon and choose to build on NEAR, you\\\\\\'ll have the chance to earn additional rewards!! We\\\\\\'ll boost your winning prize with additional rewards, giving you the support you need to keep building. So, don\\\\\\'t miss out on this incredible opportunity to showcase your skills. \\\\n\\\\n  \\\\n#### 1. How It Works \\\\u{1f929} : \\\\nParticipate in any hackathon NEAR is not sponsoring, submit a project utilizing the NEAR stack, and if you win...get ready for a bounty boost! We\\\\\\'ll match a percentage of your prize money, up to $5,000 per team. \\\\n\\\\n`EXAMPLE`: if your team wins a $2,000 prize at a hackathon and the NEAR DevHub team determines a match percentage of 50% for your submission, NEAR will boost your winnings with an additional $1000!!!\\\\n\\\\nIt\\\\\\'s that simple! Any developer anywhere in the world can benefit from the support and resources provided by **NEAR DevHub** if they choose to build on the NEAR ecosystem.\\\\n\\\\n  \\\\n#### 2. Application Process \\\\u{270d}\\\\u{fe0f} :\\\\n\\\\n- Submit your project to a **non-NEAR-sponsored hackathon**.\\\\n\\\\n- Your project must utilize tools provided by NEAR, including **Chain Abstraction, React-on-Chain, Smart Contracts in Rust (Rust, JS, AssemblyScript), SDK, and other related tools**.\\\\n\\\\n- Tweet about your submission, mentioning the hackathon, @NEARDevHub, and using hashtags: `#NEARBountyBooster, #extralife, #NEARDevHub, and #NEAR.`\\\\n\\\\n- Complete the NEAR Bounty Booster application \\\\u{1f449} [form](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfmVN4n_A0mduNVjF4PAlhllr7nQo4Xjlsei1fcA5Wvruqo2A/viewform?usp=sf_link) with project details.\\\\n\\\\n- You can submit multiple applications, but each project must be distinct.\\\\n\\\\n- Use this [sample tweet](https://typefully.com/t/bHCRD5z) as a guide.\\\\n\\\\n  \\\\n#### 3. Verification and Payment \\\\u{2705} :\\\\n- The NEAR Bounty Booster committee will verify the eligibility of the hacker team and their winning project based on the information provided in the application form and the tweet.\\\\n\\\\n- Once verified, the matched bounty amount will be paid to the hacker team within 30 days of the application submission.\\\\n  \\\\n\\\\n***Please pay attention to the terms and conditions below***\\\\n  \\\\n#### Terms & Conditions \\\\u{1f468}\\\\u{1f3fc}\\\\u{200d}\\\\u{2696}\\\\u{fe0f} : \\\\n- The exact percentage matched is determined by the NEAR DevHub team on a case-by-case basis, ensuring the program can adapt to the unique circumstances of each project and developer.\\\\n\\\\n- Each project must be distinct from the ones previously submitted for the Bounty Booster program.\\\\n\\\\n- To be considered to have \\\\\\\"won\\\\\\\" a prize, the hacker team must have been awarded one of the general prizes or sponsor-specific bounties offered by the hackathon organizers..\\\\n\\\\n- The NEAR Bounty Booster committee reserves the right to reject any application if there is an attempt to abuse the program.\\\\n\\\\n- By participating in the NEAR Bounty Booster program, hacker teams agree to these terms and conditions. The NEAR Bounty Booster committee reserves the right to modify these terms and conditions without prior notice.\\\\n\\\\n  \\\\n##### Happy Building!\\\\n", "metadata": {"id": "undefined", "title": "NEAR Bounty Booster ", "author": "victorkanu1.near", "status": "DRAFT", "category": "guide", "subtitle": "", "createdAt": "2024-04-24", "updatedAt": "2024-04-24", "description": "", "publishedAt": "2024-04-24", "communityAddonId": "blogv2"}}}}, "handle": "developer-dao"}

{"data": {"blog": {"resources-2496": {"": "##### Welcome to NEAR\\\\\\'s Developer Relations Resources! We\\\\\\'re here to guide you on your journey of building on NEAR. \\\\n \\\\nHere\\\\\\'s a curated list of resources to help you get started:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n## DevHub Reference Material & Tutorials:\\\\n- [NEAR Docs](https://docs.near.org/): Useful documentation for new developers on NEAR.\\\\n- [Build your first dApp](https://docs.near.org/develop/quickstart-guide): A quickstart guide to get you going.\\\\n- [Build a BOS component](https://docs.near.org/bos/tutorial/quickstart): Dive into BOS with this step-by-step tutorial.\\\\n- [Smart contracts with JavaScript SDK](https://docs.near.org/sdk/js/introduction): Learn to create smart contracts using JavaScript.\\\\n- [Smart contracts with Rust SDK](https://docs.near.org/sdk/rust/introduction): Explore smart contracts with Rust programming.\\\\n- [Build a front-end](https://docs.near.org/develop/integrate/frontend): A guide to building an effective front-end.\\\\n- [Indexing blockchain data](https://docs.near.org/concepts/advanced/indexers): Understand how to index blockchain data.\\\\n- [Near API JS](https://docs.near.org/tools/near-api-js/quick-reference): Quick reference for NEAR API in JavaScript.\\\\n- [Near RPC API](https://docs.near.org/api/rpc/introduction): Introduction to NEAR RPC API.\\\\n- [BOS API](https://docs.near.org/bos/api/home): Explore the BOS API.\\\\n\\\\n## Tools:\\\\n- [Near CLI](https://docs.near.org/tools/near-cli): Command-line interface for NEAR.\\\\n- [CLI RS](https://docs.near.org/tools/near-cli-rs): CLI in Rust for NEAR Protocol.\\\\n- [VSCode extension (BOS)](https://docs.near.org/bos/dev/vscode): Visual Studio Code extension for BOS.\\\\n- [BOS Loader](https://docs.near.org/bos/dev/bos-loader): Loader for BOS.\\\\n- [RPC Providers](https://docs.near.org/api/rpc/providers): Providers for NEAR RPC.\\\\n\\\\n## Examples:\\\\n- [Guestbook](https://docs.near.org/tutorials/examples/guest-book): A practical example to get you started.\\\\n- [NFTs](https://docs.near.org/develop/relevant-contracts/nft): Understand NFTs on NEAR.\\\\n- [Fungible tokens](https://docs.near.org/develop/relevant-contracts/ft): Explore creating fungible tokens.\\\\n- [Crosswords puzzle](https://docs.near.org/tutorials/crosswords/basics/overview): A fun project for hands-on learning.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nLet us know if you\\\\\\'d like us to include your tutorials, walkthroughs, courses, etc!\\\\n\\\\nIf you\\\\u{2019}d like to add links to your educational material (project walkthroughs, videos, examples, reference implementations, courses, etc) for inclusion here, reach out to us (office hours / support) and let us know! We welcome all good quality submissions.", "metadata": {"id": "2496", "title": "Resources ", "author": "victorkanu1.near", "status": "DRAFT", "category": "guide", "subtitle": "A compiled list of Resources to get you started \\\\u{1f603}", "createdAt": "2023-12-11", "updatedAt": "2023-12-11", "description": "List of Resources to get you started ", "publishedAt": "2023-12-11", "communityAddonId": "blogv2"}}}}, "handle": "devrel"}

{"data": {"blog": {"near-bounty-booster-program-3021": {"": "Calling all devs!  Get ready to take your hackathon projects to the next level with **NEAR Bounty Booster**! If you participate in any hackathon and choose to build on NEAR, you\\\\\\'ll have the chance to earn some serious cash! We\\\\\\'ll boost your prize with an extra bounty, giving you the support you need to keep building!\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n  \\\\n#### How It Works \\\\u{1f929} :\\\\n\\\\n**To be eligible for the Bounty Booster,** you must participate in any hackathon we are not sponsoring and submit a project utilizing the NEAR stack. If you win, you can claim the additional bounties the program offers. Any developer anywhere in the world can benefit from the support and resources provided by NEAR DevHub if they choose to build on the NEAR ecosystem.\\\\n\\\\nThe Bounty Booster program is designed to reward your hard work and innovation. We will match the entire prize money won by participants who use the NEAR stack in any hackathon up to a maximum of $5,000. The exact percentage matched is determined by the NEAR DevHub team on a case-by-case basis, ensuring the program can adapt to the unique circumstances of each project and developer. For example, if your team wins a $2,000 prize at a hackathon, NEAR will boost your winnings with an additional $2000!!!\\\\n\\\\nParticipating in the Bounty Booster is straightforward. After submitting a project to a non-NEAR-sponsored hackathon, Developers must fill out the following [form](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfmVN4n_A0mduNVjF4PAlhllr7nQo4Xjlsei1fcA5Wvruqo2A/viewform?usp=sf_link) and tweet about their submission using specific hashtags, tagging the relevant hackathon and @NEARDevHub. You can see a sample tweet [here](https://typefully.com/t/bHCRD5z).\\\\n\\\\nPlease review our Terms & Conditions for more information about the NEAR Bounty Booster program, including eligibility requirements, application process, and payment details. If you have further questions or need assistance, please contact us at boris@neardevhub.org.\\\\n  \\\\n## Terms & Conditions\\\\n----\\\\n  \\\\n#### Eligibility \\\\u{1f468}\\\\u{200d}\\\\u{1f4bb}:  \\\\n\\\\nTo qualify for the Bounty Booster, \\\\n\\\\n- The hacker team must submit a project using any part of the NEAR stack to a hackathon not sponsored by NEAR and win a prize. \\\\n\\\\n- To be considered to have \\\\\\\"won\\\\\\\" a prize, the hacker team must have been awarded one of the general prizes or sponsor-specific bounties offered by the hackathon organizers.\\\\n\\\\n`NOTE` The \\\\\\\"NEAR stack\\\\\\\" refers to the suite of technologies and tools provided by NEAR, including Chain Abstraction, React-on-Chain, Smart Contracts in Rust (Rust, JS, AssemblyScript), SDK, and other related tools.\\\\n\\\\n  \\\\n#### Application Process \\\\u{270d}\\\\u{fe0f}: \\\\n\\\\n- Upon submitting their project to a non-NEAR-sponsored hackathon, the hacker team must post a tweet announcing their submission.\\\\n\\\\n- The tweet must include the following: A mention of the hackathon they are participating in The @NEARDevHub handle\\\\nThe hashtags:` #NEARBountyBooster, #extralife, #NEARDevHub, and #NEAR`.\\\\n\\\\n- A sample tweet can be seen [here](https://typefully.com/t/bHCRD5z). \\\\n\\\\n- The hacker team must complete the NEAR Bounty Booster application [form](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfmVN4n_A0mduNVjF4PAlhllr7nQo4Xjlsei1fcA5Wvruqo2A/viewform?usp=sf_link), providing all required information and links to their winning project.\\\\n\\\\n- Teams can submit multiple Bounty Booster applications for projects they have submitted to non-NEAR-sponsored hackathons. Each project must be distinct from the ones previously submitted for the Bounty Booster program.\\\\n\\\\n  \\\\n#### Bounty Matching \\\\u{1f91d}: \\\\n\\\\n- The NEAR Bounty Booster program will match a portion of the bounty the eligible hacker team won in a non-NEAR-sponsored hackathon.\\\\n\\\\n- The maximum amount the program matches is $5,000 per team.\\\\n\\\\n- The NEAR Bounty Booster committee reserves the right to reject any application if there is an attempt to abuse the program.\\\\n\\\\n  \\\\n#### Verification and Payment \\\\u{2705}: \\\\n\\\\n- The NEAR Bounty Booster committee will verify the eligibility of the hacker team and their winning project based on the information provided in the application form and the tweet.\\\\n\\\\n- Once verified, the matched bounty amount will be paid to the hacker team within 30 days of the application submission.\\\\n\\\\n- Verification and payment will be subject to NF\\\\\\'s policies and T&Cs\\\\n\\\\n- By participating in the NEAR Bounty Booster program, hacker teams agree to these terms and conditions. The NEAR Bounty Booster committee reserves the right to modify these terms and conditions without prior notice.\\\\n\\\\n  \\\\n\\\\nLearn more about NEAR by checking out our \\\\u{1f449} [docs](https://docs.near.org/)\\\\n##### Happy Building!\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n![img](https://tracker.metricool.com/c3po.jpg?hash=6d58941e45233e13812f44fb26c74949)\\\\n", "metadata": {"id": "3021", "title": "NEAR Bounty Booster Program", "author": "victorkanu1.near", "status": "DRAFT", "category": "guide", "subtitle": "Get rewarded for building now and later!", "createdAt": "2024-05-02", "updatedAt": "2024-05-02", "description": "Get rewarded for building now and later!", "publishedAt": "2024-05-02", "communityAddonId": "blogv2"}}}}, "handle": "devrel"}

After submitting a project to a non-NEAR-sponsored hackathon, Developers must fill out the following [form](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfmVN4n_A0mduNVjF4PAlhllr7nQo4Xjlsei1fcA5Wvruqo2A/viewform?usp=sf_link) and tweet about their submission using specific hashtags, tagging the relevant hackathon and @NEARDevHub. You can see a sample tweet [here](https://typefully.com/t/bHCRD5z).\\\\n\\\\nPlease review our Terms & Conditions for more information about the NEAR Bounty Booster program, including eligibility requirements, application process, and payment details. If you have further questions or need assistance, please contact us at boris@neardevhub.org.\\\\n  \\\\n## Terms & Conditions\\\\n----\\\\n  \\\\n#### Eligibility \\\\u{1f468}\\\\u{200d}\\\\u{1f4bb}:  \\\\n\\\\nTo qualify for the Bounty Booster, \\\\n\\\\n- The hacker team must submit a project using any part of the NEAR stack to a hackathon not sponsored by NEAR and win a prize. \\\\n\\\\n- To be considered to have \\\\\\\"won\\\\\\\" a prize, the hacker team must have been awarded one of the general prizes or sponsor-specific bounties offered by the hackathon organizers.\\\\n\\\\n`NOTE` The \\\\\\\"NEAR stack\\\\\\\" refers to the suite of technologies and tools provided by NEAR, including Chain Abstraction, React-on-Chain, Smart Contracts in Rust (Rust, JS, AssemblyScript), SDK, and other related tools.\\\\n\\\\n  \\\\n#### Application Process \\\\u{270d}\\\\u{fe0f}: \\\\n\\\\n- Upon submitting their project to a non-NEAR-sponsored hackathon, the hacker team must post a tweet announcing their submission.\\\\n\\\\n- The tweet must include the following: A mention of the hackathon they are participating in The @NEARDevHub handle\\\\nThe hashtags:` #NEARBountyBooster, #extralife, #NEARDevHub, and #NEAR`.\\\\n\\\\n- A sample tweet can be seen [here](https://typefully.com/t/bHCRD5z). \\\\n\\\\n- The hacker team must complete the NEAR Bounty Booster application [form](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfmVN4n_A0mduNVjF4PAlhllr7nQo4Xjlsei1fcA5Wvruqo2A/viewform?usp=sf_link), providing all required information and links to their winning project.\\\\n\\\\n- Teams can submit multiple Bounty Booster applications for projects they have submitted to non-NEAR-sponsored hackathons. Each project must be distinct from the ones previously submitted for the Bounty Booster program.\\\\n\\\\n  \\\\n#### Bounty Matching \\\\u{1f91d}: \\\\n\\\\n- The NEAR Bounty Booster program will match a portion of the bounty the eligible hacker team won in a non-NEAR-sponsored hackathon.\\\\n\\\\n- The maximum amount the program matches is $5,000 per team.\\\\n\\\\n- The NEAR Bounty Booster committee reserves the right to reject any application if there is an attempt to abuse the program.\\\\n\\\\n  \\\\n#### Verification and Payment \\\\u{2705}: \\\\n\\\\n- The NEAR Bounty Booster committee will verify the eligibility of the hacker team and their winning project based on the information provided in the application form and the tweet.\\\\n\\\\n- Once verified, the matched bounty amount will be paid to the hacker team within 30 days of the application submission.\\\\n\\\\n- Verification and payment will be subject to NF\\\\\\'s policies and T&Cs\\\\n\\\\n- By participating in the NEAR Bounty Booster program, hacker teams agree to these terms and conditions. The NEAR Bounty Booster committee reserves the right to modify these terms and conditions without prior notice.\\\\n\\\\n  \\\\n\\\\nLearn more about NEAR by checking out our \\\\u{1f449} [docs](https://docs.near.org/)\\\\n##### Happy Building!\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n![img](https://tracker.metricool.com/c3po.jpg?hash=6d58941e45233e13812f44fb26c74949)\\\\n", "metadata": {"id": "3021", "title": "NEAR Bounty Booster Program", "author": "victorkanu1.near", "status": "DRAFT", "category": "guide", "subtitle": "Get rewarded for building now and later!", "createdAt": "2024-05-02", "updatedAt": "2024-05-02", "description": "Get rewarded for building now and later!", "publishedAt": "2024-05-02", "communityAddonId": "blogv2"}}}}}}

Providers](https://docs.near.org/api/rpc/providers): Providers for NEAR RPC.\\\\n\\\\n## Examples:\\\\n- [Guestbook](https://docs.near.org/tutorials/examples/guest-book): A practical example to get include your tutorials, walkthroughs, courses, etc!\\\\n\\\\nIf you\\\\u{2019}d like to add links to your educational material (project walkthroughs, videos, examples, reference implementations, {"data": {"blog": {"near-bounty-booster-program-3021": {"": "Calling all devs!  Get ready to take your hackathon projects to the next level with **NEAR Bounty Booster**! If you participate in any hackathon and choose to build on NEAR, you\\\\\\'ll have the chance to earn some serious cash! We\\\\\\'ll boost your prize with an extra bounty, giving you the support you need to keep building!\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n  \\\\n#### How It Works \\\\u{1f929} :\\\\n\\\\n**To be eligible for the Bounty Booster,** you must participate in any hackathon we are not sponsoring and submit a project utilizing the NEAR stack. If you win, you can claim the additional bounties the program offers. Any developer anywhere in the world can benefit from the support and resources provided by NEAR DevHub if they choose to build on the NEAR ecosystem.\\\\n\\\\nThe Bounty Booster program is designed to reward your hard work and innovation. We will match the entire prize money won by participants who use the NEAR stack in any hackathon up to a maximum of $5,000. The exact percentage matched is determined by the NEAR DevHub team on a case-by-case basis, ensuring the program can adapt to the unique circumstances of each project and developer. For example, if your team wins a $2,000 prize at a hackathon, NEAR will boost your winnings with an additional $2000!!!\\\\n\\\\nParticipating in the Bounty Booster is straightforward. After submitting a project to a non-NEAR-sponsored hackathon, Developers must fill out the following [form](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfmVN4n_A0mduNVjF4PAlhllr7nQo4Xjlsei1fcA5Wvruqo2A/viewform?usp=sf_link) and tweet about their submission using specific hashtags, tagging the relevant hackathon and @NEARDevHub. You can see a sample tweet [here](https://typefully.com/t/bHCRD5z).\\\\n\\\\nPlease review our Terms & Conditions for more information about the NEAR Bounty Booster program, including eligibility requirements, application process, and payment details. If you have further questions or need assistance, please contact us at boris@neardevhub.org.\\\\n  \\\\n## Terms & Conditions\\\\n----\\\\n  \\\\n#### Eligibility \\\\u{1f468}\\\\u{200d}\\\\u{1f4bb}:  \\\\n\\\\nTo qualify for the Bounty Booster, \\\\n\\\\n- The hacker team must submit a project using any part of the NEAR stack to a hackathon not sponsored by NEAR and win a prize. \\\\n\\\\n- To be considered to have \\\\\\\"won\\\\\\\" a prize, the hacker team must have been awarded one of the general prizes or sponsor-specific bounties offered by the hackathon organizers.\\\\n\\\\n`NOTE` The \\\\\\\"NEAR stack\\\\\\\" refers to the suite of technologies and tools provided by NEAR, including Chain Abstraction, React-on-Chain, Smart Contracts in Rust (Rust, JS, AssemblyScript), SDK, and other related tools.\\\\n\\\\n  \\\\n#### Application Process \\\\u{270d}\\\\u{fe0f}: \\\\n\\\\n- Upon submitting their project to a non-NEAR-sponsored hackathon, the hacker team must post a tweet announcing their submission.\\\\n\\\\n- The tweet must include the following: A mention of the hackathon they are participating in The @NEARDevHub handle\\\\nThe hashtags:` #NEARBountyBooster, #extralife, #NEARDevHub, and #NEAR`.\\\\n\\\\n- A sample tweet can be seen [here](https://typefully.com/t/bHCRD5z). \\\\n\\\\n- The hacker team must complete the NEAR Bounty Booster application [form](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfmVN4n_A0mduNVjF4PAlhllr7nQo4Xjlsei1fcA5Wvruqo2A/viewform?usp=sf_link), providing all required information and links to their winning project.\\\\n\\\\n- Teams can submit multiple Bounty Booster applications for projects they have submitted to non-NEAR-sponsored hackathons. Each project must be distinct from the ones previously submitted for the Bounty Booster program.\\\\n\\\\n  \\\\n#### Bounty Matching \\\\u{1f91d}: \\\\n\\\\n- The NEAR Bounty Booster program will match a portion of the bounty the eligible hacker team won in a non-NEAR-sponsored hackathon.\\\\n\\\\n- The maximum amount the program matches is $5,000 per team.\\\\n\\\\n- The NEAR Bounty Booster committee reserves the right to reject any application if there is an attempt to abuse the program.\\\\n\\\\n  \\\\n#### Verification and Payment \\\\u{2705}: \\\\n\\\\n- The NEAR Bounty Booster committee will verify the eligibility of the hacker team and their winning project based on the information provided in the application form and the tweet.\\\\n\\\\n- Once verified, the matched bounty amount will be paid to the hacker team within 30 days of the application submission.\\\\n\\\\n- Verification and payment will be subject to NF\\\\\\'s policies and T&Cs\\\\n\\\\n- By participating in the NEAR Bounty Booster program, hacker teams agree to these terms and conditions. The NEAR Bounty Booster committee reserves the right to modify these terms and conditions without prior notice.\\\\n\\\\n  \\\\n\\\\nLearn more about NEAR by checking out our \\\\u{1f449} [docs](https://docs.near.org/)\\\\n##### Happy Building!\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n![img](https://tracker.metricool.com/c3po.jpg?hash=6d58941e45233e13812f44fb26c74949)\\\\n", "metadata": {"id": "3021", "title": "NEAR Bounty Booster Program", "author": "victorkanu1.near", "status": "DRAFT", "category": "guide", "subtitle": "Get rewarded for building now and later!", "createdAt": "2024-05-02", "updatedAt": "2024-05-02", "description": "Get rewarded for building now and later!", "publishedAt": "2024-05-02", "communityAddonId": "blogv2"}}}}, "handle": "devrel"}

{"data": {"blog": {"running-an-rpc-node-3022": {"": "**In recent news, NEAR announced a partncership with LAVA network to scale the RPC service providers by incentivising node operators. Let\\\\\\'s take this opportunity to talk about what these RPC nodes are and how to run one ourselves.***\\\\n\\\\n## What is an RPC node?\\\\nAn RPC (Remote Procedure Call) node is a system that connects the blockchain with the outside world. This way, users and applications can request information from the blockchain through these RPC nodes and send transactions to be processed.\\\\n\\\\n#### Why would we want to run an RPC node?\\\\nOne would want to run their own RPC node for multiple reasons. One reason might be having a dedicated RPC for your users and applications so you do not need to rely on public RPCs that might get congested. Another reason is to contribute your node to a private RPC endpoint to help it scale, thus improving the throughput of the network services.\\\\n\\\\n#### Before we start\\\\nThis article will follow the official node docs, focusing on setting up a basic node for testnet.\\\\n\\\\n`warning: This article will not dwell on server security (e.g., setting up firewalls, rate limiters, etc). We encourage you to read more about hardening (securing) your server and its services.`\\\\n\\\\n#### The Hardware\\\\nThe recommended hardware section on the node docs lists the following config:\\\\n\\\\nHardware\\\\nRecommended Specifications\\\\nCPU\\\\n8-Core (16-Thread) Intel i7/Xeon or equivalent with AVX support|\\\\nCPU Features\\\\nCMPXCHG16B, POPCNT, SSE4.1, SSE4.2, AVX\\\\nRAM\\\\n20GB DDR4\\\\nStorage\\\\n1TB NVMe SSD\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nRPC nodes store the last five epochs of data, requiring a large amount of storage to accommodate this. However, this amount may vary due to network activity and protocol upgrades, so it\\\\\\'s always better to exceed the recommendations a bit.\\\\n\\\\nIf we don\\\\\\'t have a machine with such specifications, we can choose a server provider such as Azure, AWS, Google Cloud, Hetzner, or OVH, just to name a few.\\\\n\\\\n#### Setting up\\\\nAfter spinning up our server, we can begin setting up our node.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\tinfo\\\\n\\\\tSince it is a popular distribution, we will use `Ubuntu 22.04`, so your actual command lines may vary.\\\\n\\\\nThe following lines will install the necessary packages needed by nearcore and some tools that we will need later.\\\\n\\\\n```bash\\\\n# Update system and install relevant apps\\\\n$ sudo apt update\\\\n$ sudo apt install -y git binutils-dev libcurl4-openssl-dev zlib1g-dev libdw-dev libiberty-dev cmake gcc g++ python-is-python3 docker.io protobuf-compiler libssl-dev pkg-config clang llvm cargo awscli httpie\\\\n\\\\n# Install Rust\\\\n$ curl --proto \\\\\\'=https\\\\\\' --tlsv1.2 -sSf https://sh.rustup.rs | sh -s -- -y\\\\n$ source \\\\\\\"$HOME/.cargo/env\\\\\\\"\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n#### Getting and Compiling nearcore\\\\nWhen writing the latest `nearcore` release is `1.37.0`, make sure to check the latest version on the GitHub repo.\\\\n\\\\nLet\\\\\\'s clone the repository, compile the code, and move the resulting binary into `/usr/local/bin`\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n$ git clone https://github.com/near/nearcore\\\\n$ cd nearcore\\\\n$ git fetch origin --tags\\\\n$ git checkout tags/1.36.5 -b my_rpc_node\\\\n$ make release\\\\n$ sudo mv /nearcore/target/release/neard /usr/local/bin/neard\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n#### Initialize a working directory\\\\nTo run an RPC node we need to initialize a working directory, obtaining the genesis configuration of the blockchain.\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n$ neard init --chain-id testnet --download-genesis\\\\n$ wget https://s3-us-west-1.amazonaws.com/build.nearprotocol.com/nearcore-deploy/testnet/config.json -P ~/.near/\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n`warning\\\\nWe recommend you run this command with a designated [service account](https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/314725/what-is-the-difference-between-user-and-service-account). Do not run it as the `root` user.`\\\\n\\\\n#### Replacing the default configuration\\\\nLet\\\\\\'s remove the default configuration and get the pre-populated one provided by NEAR.\\\\nSyncing with the last backup\\\\nAs a final step before running the node, we must first sync up with the network. This means our node needs to download all the headers and blocks that other nodes in the network already have.\\\\n\\\\nBackups are frequently updated, so we need to determine which one is the latest before syncing the data from it.\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n$ aws s3 --no-sign-request cp s3://near-protocol public/backups/testnet/rpc/latest .\\\\n$ LATEST=$(cat latest)\\\\n$ aws s3 --no-sign-request cp --no-sign-request --recursive s3://near-protocol-public/backups/testnet/rpc/$LATEST ~/.near/data\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n`info`: This will take a while, so you might want to make use of [screen](https://quickref.me/screen) or [tmux](https://github.com/tmux/tmux/wiki), which we will not be covered in this article\\\\n\\\\n#### Running the node\\\\nStart the node by running\\\\n\\\\n```bash\\\\n$ neard --home /root/.near run\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nOur node has synced with the last backup available, but since some time has passed, it will need to catch up with the remaining blocks it missed. At this point, it is normal to see messages such as:\\\\n\\\\n`WARN chunks: Error processing partial encoded chunk response: UnknownChunk`\\\\nor\\\\n`ERROR network: Failed to store connection attempt. peer_info=PeerInfo ....`\\\\n\\\\nAfter a while, it should have caught up with the network, and the logs output would look similar:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n**Congratulations! Our node is running, and we will see the logs output as long as we keep the process alive.**\\\\n\\\\n#### Persisting the process\\\\nExplain [todo]\\\\nCreate a `near.service` file in `/etc/systemd/system/` with the following content:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n[Unit]\\\\nDescription=NEAR RPC node\\\\nAfter=network-online.target\\\\n\\\\n[Service]\\\\nUser=root\\\\nExecStart=/usr/local/bin/neard --home /root/.near run\\\\nRestart=always\\\\nRestartSec=10\\\\nLimitNOFILE=65535\\\\n\\\\n[Install]\\\\nWantedBy=multi-user.target\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nTo make use of our newly created service, we should reload systemctl and enable it\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n$ systemctl daemon-reload\\\\n$ systemctl enable near.service\\\\n$ systemctl start near\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nOnce the process starts, we can use the following command to follow the output logs\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\njournalctl --fu near -o cat\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nThis time if we hit `[ctrl]+[c]` the logs would be closed, but our node will continue running in the background.\\\\nInteract locally\\\\n\\\\nNow that our node is up and running persistently, it is ready to receive http requests via `http://localhost:3030`. To learn more on how to interact with RPC nodes, we can refer to the documentation [found here](https://docs.near.org/api/rpc/introduction#near-rpc---quick-links)\\\\n\\\\nLet\\\\\\'s get the answer to life, the universe, and everything by calling the function `get_answer` on the smart contract deployed on `the_answer.testnet`.\\\\n\\\\nTo make the call, we will use [httpie](https://httpie.io/), which we installed already with the packages in the beginning\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n$ http post http://localhost:3030 jsonrpc=2.0 id=dontcare method=query \\\\\\\\  params:=\\\\\\'{    \\\\n    \\\\\\\"request_type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"call_function\\\\\\\",    \\\\n    \\\\\\\"finality\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"final\\\\\\\",    \\\\n    \\\\\\\"account_id\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"the_answer.testnet\\\\\\\",    \\\\n    \\\\\\\"method_name\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"get_answer\\\\\\\",    \\\\n    \\\\\\\"args_base64\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"e30=\\\\\\\"  \\\\n}\\\\\\'\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n#### Interact from across the world\\\\nIf we try accessing the running service from outside of our server, it will fail because the service is only accessible from within our machine or the local network we are part of. While port forwarding is an option, setting up a reverse proxy is a much better approach.\\\\n\\\\n**What is a reverse proxy?**\\\\n> *A reverse proxy is a server that sits before web servers and forwards client (e.g., web browser) requests to those web servers. Reverse proxies are typically implemented to help increase security, performance, and reliability*.\\\\n> [CloudFlare on proxies](https://www.cloudflare.com/learning/cdn/glossary/reverse-proxy/)\\\\nReverse Proxy with NGINX\\\\n[NGINX](https://www.nginx.com/) is an open-source web server that can also be used for load balancing, server caching and as a reverse proxy.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nNow that we have a general idea of what *reverse proxy* is and how it would benefit our node, let\\\\\\'s go ahead and Install nginx.\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n$ apt install nginx\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nWe should create an nginx server config file in `/etc/nginx/sites-available/`\\\\nWe can name the file anything we want, but usually, the name would be the domain name we are configuring.\\\\n\\\\n*We can learn more about on nginx and configuration on the [nginx docs](https://docs.nginx.com/nginx/admin-guide/web-server/reverse-proxy/)*\\\\n\\\\nLet\\\\\\'s go with `myRPC` with the following content\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n# content of /etc/nginx/sites-available/myRPC\\\\n\\\\nserver {\\\\n\\\\tlisten 80;\\\\n\\\\tlisten [::]:80;\\\\n\\\\n\\\\tserver_name YOUR_SERVER_IP_HERE; # or domain name if you have set one up\\\\n\\\\n\\\\tlocation / {\\\\n    \\\\tproxy_pass http://localhost:3030;\\\\n    \\\\tinclude proxy_params;\\\\n\\\\t}\\\\n}\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nWe can test our nginx config with the following command\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n$ nginx -t\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nAfter ensuring that our configurations are correct, we can enable our server by linking to it in the `sites-enabled` directory.\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n$ ln -s /etc/nginx/sites-available/myRpc /etc/nginx/sites-enabled/\\\\n$ systemctl restart nginx\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nWe can use httpie from our personal computer (or anywhere in the world really) and interact with the node from outside of the local network of our server\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n$ http post http://123.123.123 jsonrpc=2.0 id=dontcare method=query \\\\\\\\\\\\n  params:=\\\\\\'{\\\\n\\\\t\\\\\\\"request_type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"call_function\\\\\\\",\\\\n\\\\t\\\\\\\"finality\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"final\\\\\\\",\\\\n\\\\t\\\\\\\"account_id\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"the_answer.testnet\\\\\\\",\\\\n\\\\t\\\\\\\"method_name\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"get_answer\\\\\\\",\\\\n\\\\t\\\\\\\"args_base64\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"e30=\\\\\\\"\\\\n  }\\\\\\'\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nA successfully returned query will include `\\\\\\\"result\\\\\\\":` with an array of bytes `[52, 50]` in JavaScript we can turn it into a human-readable string like so\\\\n\\\\n```js\\\\nString.fromCharCode(...[52, 50])\\\\n\\\\\\'42\\\\\\'\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n#### Enabling SSL\\\\n\\\\nIf we already have a domain pointed to our server, enabling SSL can be relatively easy using guided tools such as [certbot](https://certbot.eff.org/).\\\\n\\\\nWe must use a Self-Signed Certificate if we need to get a domain name but want to add SSL to NGINX. Luckily, some articles cover this already, such as [this one](https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-create-a-self-signed-ssl-certificate-for-nginx-in-ubuntu-20-04-1) from DigitalOcean.\\\\n\\\\nAfter enabling SSL, our config file in `sites-available` would look something like this:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\nserver {\\\\n\\\\tlisten [::]:443 ssl ipv6only=on; # managed by Certbot\\\\n\\\\tlisten 443 ssl; # managed by Certbot\\\\n\\\\n\\\\tserver_name YOUR_DOMAIN_HERE; # your domain here\\\\n\\\\n\\\\tssl_certificate /etc/letsencrypt/live/YOUR_DOMAIN_HERE/fullchain.pem; # managed by Certbot\\\\n\\\\tssl_certificate_key /etc/letsencrypt/live/YOUR_DOMAIN_HERE; # managed by Certbot\\\\n\\\\tinclude /etc/letsencrypt/options-ssl-nginx.conf; # managed by Certbot\\\\n\\\\tssl_dhparam /etc/letsencrypt/ssl-dhparams.pem; # managed by Certbot\\\\n\\\\n\\\\tlocation / {\\\\n    \\\\tproxy_pass http://localhost:3030;\\\\n\\\\t}\\\\n}\\\\n\\\\nserver {\\\\n\\\\tif ($host = YOUR_DOMAIN_HERE) {\\\\n    \\\\treturn 301 https://$host$request_uri;\\\\n\\\\t} # managed by Certbot\\\\n\\\\n\\\\tlisten 80;\\\\n\\\\tlisten [::]:80;\\\\n\\\\n\\\\tserver_name YOUR_DOMAIN_HERE;\\\\n\\\\treturn 404; # managed by Certbot\\\\n}\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n#### Conclusion\\\\nIn this article, we delved a bit into RPC nodes, which serve as pivotal connectors between applications and the blockchain.\\\\n\\\\nAt this point, we have a running node ready to use as a personal service. Before opening it to the public, we should secure the server further and implement rate limiting.\\\\n", "metadata": {"id": "3022", "title": "Running an RPC Node", "author": "victorkanu1.near", "status": "DRAFT", "category": "guide", "subtitle": "", "createdAt": "2024-02-18", "updatedAt": "2024-02-18", "description": "", "publishedAt": "2024-02-18", "communityAddonId": "blogv2"}}}}, "handle": "devrel"}

Let\\\\\\'s take this opportunity to talk about what these RPC nodes are and how to run one ourselves.***\\\\n\\\\n## What is an RPC node?\\\\nAn RPC (Remote Procedure Call) node is a system that connects the blockchain with the outside world. This way, users and applications can request information from the blockchain through these RPC nodes and send transactions to be processed.\\\\n\\\\n#### Why would we want to run an RPC node?\\\\nOne would want to run their own RPC node for multiple reasons. One reason might be having a dedicated RPC for your users and applications so you do not need to rely on public RPCs that might get congested. Another reason is to contribute your node to a private RPC endpoint to help it scale, thus improving the throughput of the network services.\\\\n\\\\n#### Before we start\\\\nThis article will follow the official node docs, focusing on setting up a basic node for testnet.\\\\n\\\\n`warning: This article will not dwell on server security (e.g., setting up firewalls, rate limiters, etc). We encourage you to read more about hardening (securing) your server and its services.`\\\\n\\\\n#### The Hardware\\\\nThe recommended hardware section on the node docs lists the following config:\\\\n\\\\nHardware\\\\nRecommended Specifications\\\\nCPU\\\\n8-Core (16-Thread) Intel i7/Xeon or equivalent with AVX support|\\\\nCPU Features\\\\nCMPXCHG16B, POPCNT, SSE4.1, SSE4.2, AVX\\\\nRAM\\\\n20GB DDR4\\\\nStorage\\\\n1TB NVMe SSD\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nRPC nodes store the last five epochs of data, requiring a large amount of storage to accommodate this. However, this amount may vary due to network activity and protocol upgrades, so it\\\\\\'s always better to exceed the recommendations a bit.\\\\n\\\\nIf we don\\\\\\'t have a machine with such specifications, we can choose a server provider such as Azure, AWS, Google Cloud, Hetzner, or OVH, just to name a few.\\\\n\\\\n#### Setting up\\\\nAfter spinning up our server, we can begin setting up our node.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\tinfo\\\\n\\\\tSince it is a popular distribution, we will use `Ubuntu 22.04`, so your actual command lines may vary.\\\\n\\\\nThe following lines will install the necessary packages needed by nearcore and some tools that we will need later.\\\\n\\\\n```bash\\\\n# Update system and install relevant apps\\\\n$ sudo apt update\\\\n$ sudo apt install -y git binutils-dev libcurl4-openssl-dev zlib1g-dev libdw-dev libiberty-dev cmake gcc g++ python-is-python3 docker.io protobuf-compiler libssl-dev pkg-config clang llvm cargo awscli httpie\\\\n\\\\n# Install Rust\\\\n$ curl --proto \\\\\\'=https\\\\\\' --tlsv1.2 -sSf https://sh.rustup.rs | sh -s -- -y\\\\n$ source \\\\\\\"$HOME/.cargo/env\\\\\\\"\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n#### Getting and Compiling nearcore\\\\nWhen writing the latest `nearcore` release is `1.37.0`, make sure to check the latest version on the GitHub repo.\\\\n\\\\nLet\\\\\\'s clone the repository, compile the code, and move the resulting binary into `/usr/local/bin`\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n$ git clone https://github.com/near/nearcore\\\\n$ cd nearcore\\\\n$ git fetch origin --tags\\\\n$ git checkout tags/1.36.5 -b my_rpc_node\\\\n$ make release\\\\n$ sudo mv /nearcore/target/release/neard /usr/local/bin/neard\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n#### Initialize a working directory\\\\nTo run an RPC node we need to initialize a working directory, obtaining the genesis configuration of the blockchain.\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n$ neard init --chain-id testnet --download-genesis\\\\n$ wget https://s3-us-west-1.amazonaws.com/build.nearprotocol.com/nearcore-deploy/testnet/config.json -P ~/.near/\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n`warning\\\\nWe recommend you run this command with a designated [service account](https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/314725/what-is-the-difference-between-user-and-service-account). Do not run it as the `root` user.`\\\\n\\\\n#### Replacing the default configuration\\\\nLet\\\\\\'s remove the default configuration and get the pre-populated one provided by NEAR.\\\\nSyncing with the last backup\\\\nAs a final step before running the node, we must first sync up with the network. This means our node needs to download all the headers and blocks that other nodes in the network already have.\\\\n\\\\nBackups are frequently updated, so we need to determine which one is the latest before syncing the data from it.\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n$ aws s3 --no-sign-request cp s3://near-protocol public/backups/testnet/rpc/latest .\\\\n$ LATEST=$(cat latest)\\\\n$ aws s3 --no-sign-request cp --no-sign-request --recursive s3://near-protocol-public/backups/testnet/rpc/$LATEST ~/.near/data\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n`info`: This will take a while, so you might want to make use of [screen](https://quickref.me/screen) or [tmux](https://github.com/tmux/tmux/wiki), which we will not be covered in this article\\\\n\\\\n#### Running the node\\\\nStart the node by running\\\\n\\\\n```bash\\\\n$ neard --home /root/.near run\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nOur node has synced with the last backup available, but since some time has passed, it will need to catch up with the remaining blocks it missed. At this point, it is normal to see messages such as:\\\\n\\\\n`WARN chunks: Error processing partial encoded chunk response: UnknownChunk`\\\\nor\\\\n`ERROR network: Failed to store connection attempt. peer_info=PeerInfo ....`\\\\n\\\\nAfter a while, it should have caught up with the network, and the logs output would look similar:\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n**Congratulations! Our node is running, and we will see the logs output as long as we keep the process alive.**\\\\n\\\\n#### Persisting the process\\\\nExplain [todo]\\\\nCreate a `near.service` file in `/etc/systemd/system/` with the following content:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n[Unit]\\\\nDescription=NEAR RPC node\\\\nAfter=network-online.target\\\\n\\\\n[Service]\\\\nUser=root\\\\nExecStart=/usr/local/bin/neard --home /root/.near run\\\\nRestart=always\\\\nRestartSec=10\\\\nLimitNOFILE=65535\\\\n\\\\n[Install]\\\\nWantedBy=multi-user.target\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nTo make use of our newly created service, we should reload systemctl and enable it\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n$ systemctl daemon-reload\\\\n$ systemctl enable near.service\\\\n$ systemctl start near\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nOnce the process starts, we can use the following command to follow the output logs\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\njournalctl --fu near -o cat\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nThis time if we hit `[ctrl]+[c]` the logs would be closed, but our node will continue running in the background.\\\\nInteract locally\\\\n\\\\nNow that our node is up and running persistently, it is ready to receive http requests via `http://localhost:3030`. To learn more on how to interact with RPC nodes, we can refer to the documentation [found here](https://docs.near.org/api/rpc/introduction#near-rpc---quick-links)\\\\n\\\\nLet\\\\\\'s get the answer to life, the universe, and everything by calling the function `get_answer` on the smart contract deployed on `the_answer.testnet`.\\\\n\\\\nTo make the call, we will use [httpie](https://httpie.io/), which we installed already with the packages in the beginning\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n$ http post http://localhost:3030 jsonrpc=2.0 id=dontcare method=query \\\\\\\\  params:=\\\\\\'{    \\\\n    \\\\\\\"request_type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"call_function\\\\\\\",    \\\\n    \\\\\\\"finality\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"final\\\\\\\",    \\\\n    \\\\\\\"account_id\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"the_answer.testnet\\\\\\\",    \\\\n    \\\\\\\"method_name\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"get_answer\\\\\\\",    \\\\n    \\\\\\\"args_base64\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"e30=\\\\\\\"  \\\\n}\\\\\\'\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n#### Interact from across the world\\\\nIf we try accessing the running service from outside of our server, it will fail because the service is only accessible from within our machine or the local network we are part of. While port forwarding is an option, setting up a reverse proxy is a much better approach.\\\\n\\\\n**What is a reverse proxy?**\\\\n> *A reverse proxy is a server that sits before web servers and forwards client (e.g., web browser) requests to those web servers. Reverse proxies are typically implemented to help increase security, performance, and reliability*.\\\\n> [CloudFlare on proxies](https://www.cloudflare.com/learning/cdn/glossary/reverse-proxy/)\\\\nReverse Proxy with NGINX\\\\n[NGINX](https://www.nginx.com/) is an open-source web server that can also be used for load balancing, server caching and as a reverse proxy.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nNow that we have a general idea of what *reverse proxy* is and how it would benefit our node, let\\\\\\'s go ahead and Install nginx.\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n$ apt install nginx\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nWe should create an nginx server config file in `/etc/nginx/sites-available/`\\\\nWe can name the file anything we want, but usually, the name would be the domain name we are configuring.\\\\n\\\\n*We can learn more about on nginx and configuration on the [nginx docs](https://docs.nginx.com/nginx/admin-guide/web-server/reverse-proxy/)*\\\\n\\\\nLet\\\\\\'s go with `myRPC` with the following content\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n# content of /etc/nginx/sites-available/myRPC\\\\n\\\\nserver {\\\\n\\\\tlisten 80;\\\\n\\\\tlisten [::]:80;\\\\n\\\\n\\\\tserver_name YOUR_SERVER_IP_HERE; # or domain name if you have set one up\\\\n\\\\n\\\\tlocation / {\\\\n    \\\\tproxy_pass http://localhost:3030;\\\\n    \\\\tinclude proxy_params;\\\\n\\\\t}\\\\n}\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nWe can test our nginx config with the following command\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n$ nginx -t\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nAfter ensuring that our configurations are correct, we can enable our server by linking to it in the `sites-enabled` directory.\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n$ ln -s /etc/nginx/sites-available/myRpc /etc/nginx/sites-enabled/\\\\n$ systemctl restart nginx\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nWe can use httpie from our personal computer (or anywhere in the world really) and interact with the node from outside of the local network of our server\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\n$ http post http://123.123.123 jsonrpc=2.0 id=dontcare method=query \\\\\\\\\\\\n  params:=\\\\\\'{\\\\n\\\\t\\\\\\\"request_type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"call_function\\\\\\\",\\\\n\\\\t\\\\\\\"finality\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"final\\\\\\\",\\\\n\\\\t\\\\\\\"account_id\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"the_answer.testnet\\\\\\\",\\\\n\\\\t\\\\\\\"method_name\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"get_answer\\\\\\\",\\\\n\\\\t\\\\\\\"args_base64\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"e30=\\\\\\\"\\\\n  }\\\\\\'\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\nA successfully returned query will include `\\\\\\\"result\\\\\\\":` with an array of bytes `[52, 50]` in JavaScript we can turn it into a human-readable string like so\\\\n\\\\n```js\\\\nString.fromCharCode(...[52, 50])\\\\n\\\\\\'42\\\\\\'\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n#### Enabling SSL\\\\n\\\\nIf we already have a domain pointed to our server, enabling SSL can be relatively easy using guided tools such as [certbot](https://certbot.eff.org/).\\\\n\\\\nWe must use a Self-Signed Certificate if we need to get a domain name but want to add SSL to NGINX. Luckily, some articles cover this already, such as [this one](https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-create-a-self-signed-ssl-certificate-for-nginx-in-ubuntu-20-04-1) from DigitalOcean.\\\\n\\\\nAfter enabling SSL, our config file in `sites-available` would look something like this:\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\nserver {\\\\n\\\\tlisten [::]:443 ssl ipv6only=on; # managed by Certbot\\\\n\\\\tlisten 443 ssl; # managed by Certbot\\\\n\\\\n\\\\tserver_name YOUR_DOMAIN_HERE; # your domain here\\\\n\\\\n\\\\tssl_certificate /etc/letsencrypt/live/YOUR_DOMAIN_HERE/fullchain.pem; # managed by Certbot\\\\n\\\\tssl_certificate_key /etc/letsencrypt/live/YOUR_DOMAIN_HERE; # managed by Certbot\\\\n\\\\tinclude /etc/letsencrypt/options-ssl-nginx.conf; # managed by Certbot\\\\n\\\\tssl_dhparam /etc/letsencrypt/ssl-dhparams.pem; # managed by Certbot\\\\n\\\\n\\\\tlocation / {\\\\n    \\\\tproxy_pass http://localhost:3030;\\\\n\\\\t}\\\\n}\\\\n\\\\nserver {\\\\n\\\\tif ($host = YOUR_DOMAIN_HERE) {\\\\n    \\\\treturn 301 https://$host$request_uri;\\\\n\\\\t} # managed by Certbot\\\\n\\\\n\\\\tlisten 80;\\\\n\\\\tlisten [::]:80;\\\\n\\\\n\\\\tserver_name YOUR_DOMAIN_HERE;\\\\n\\\\treturn 404; # managed by Certbot\\\\n}\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n#### Conclusion\\\\nIn this article, we delved a bit into RPC nodes, which serve as pivotal connectors between applications and the blockchain.\\\\n\\\\nAt this point, we have a running node ready to use as a personal service. {"data": {"blog": {"devhub-livestream-3292": {"": "**Moderated by:** @orangejoe.near\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n## Summary\\\\n\\\\nThe livestream featured a conversation with Brandon and Owen, two developers who are actively building projects on the NEAR ecosystem. They shared insights into their experiences as builders and discussed the current state of NEAR.\\\\n\\\\n1. **Project Updates**: Brandon and Owen discussed several projects they are involved in, including Jump DeFi Vaults and Nico, which recently got listed on the MEXC exchange. They highlighted the growth and development of these projects within the NEAR ecosystem.\\\\n\\\\n2. **Developer Experience**: The conversation touched upon the developer experience on NEAR, with Brandon and Owen sharing their perspectives on building projects and hiring developers within the ecosystem. They discussed the importance of finding developers with contract experience and the potential for AI to augment development processes.\\\\n\\\\n3. **Chain Abstraction**: Brandon and Owen highlighted the significance of chain abstraction within the NEAR ecosystem, emphasizing its role in expanding the platform\\\\\\'s capabilities and attracting developers from other chains. They discussed how NEAR\\\\\\'s infrastructure and low transaction fees make it an attractive platform for building decentralized applications.\\\\n\\\\n4. **Scalability Solutions**: NEAR\\\\\\'s scalability solutions were discussed, particularly dynamic resharding, which enables the platform to handle increasing transaction volumes without compromising performance. They emphasized the importance of scalability in supporting the growth of projects and attracting users.\\\\n\\\\n5. **Opportunities for Developers**: Brandon and Owen encouraged developers to explore opportunities within the NEAR ecosystem, highlighting the availability of resources such as Horizon to support budding entrepreneurs. They emphasized the potential for developers to build innovative projects and contribute to the growth of the ecosystem.\\\\n\\\\n6. **Bounty Booster Program**: The livestream promoted the Bounty Booster program, which incentivizes developers to incorporate NEAR into their projects by offering boosts for bounty winnings. Brandon and Owen encouraged developers participating in hackathons to take advantage of the program to enhance their projects and earn rewards.\\\\n\\\\nThe livestream concluded with a call to action for developers to engage with the NEAR community, participate in hackathons, and explore opportunities for building on the platform. Brandon and Owen encouraged developers to join NEAR\\\\\\'s Telegram channel, subscribe to the newsletter, and stay updated on upcoming events and initiatives.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n##### Check out the recording [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5WYcgg4Z5H0)", "metadata": {"id": "3292", "title": "DevHub Livestream ", "author": "victorkanu1.near", "status": "DRAFT", "category": "guide", "subtitle": "Episode 4", "createdAt": "2024-05-15", "updatedAt": "2024-05-15", "description": "Episode 4", "publishedAt": "2024-05-15", "communityAddonId": "blogv2"}}}}, "handle": "devhub-marketing"}
